prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HCN, CO, CS, HCO+
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This correlator setup/SG should ideally be observed in direct succession with the others.

prj:TemporalParameters.prj:note: This correlator setup/SG should ideally be observed in direct succession with the others.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Correlator Setup: This correlator setting covers lines of HCN, CO, CS and HCO+ (see Table 1)
A spectral resolution of 488~kHz will be sufficient to resolve these lines of interest, which have expected FWHM of 1-2 km/s.
Requested sensitivity and angular resolution: Adopting typical values for the chemical mixing ratios (and a nominal abundance of 10% for HNC relative to HCN), predicted emission line strengths for the proposed lines in K1 PanSTARRS are given in Table 1. These were calculated using a Haser-type model with an outflow velocity of 1 km/s and excitation temperature of 50 K. The optimal combination of spectral line signal-to-noise and angular resolution for the species of interest is achieved with ALMA band 7. The array is likely to be in a mid-compact configuration in September/October 2014, which will provide an angular resolution of approx. 0.50-1.0'' in band 6 and 7. In order to accurately measure spatial-spectral emission profiles, we require S/N >~ 20 per resolution element (which also allows for some uncertainty in molecular abundance and excitation). Integration times were calculated accordingly using the Cycle 2 observing tool with 34x12-m dishes and, default atmospheric parameters and a source declination of -10 degrees. Band 7 visibilities will be tapered to match the angular resolution in band 6 to facilitate intercomparison of the spectral lines.
Imaging requirements: Assuming a relatively compact configuration, the minimum and maximum angular scales probed will be around 0.7'' and 10'', respectively, and the FOV is approx. 25''. The total extent of the molecular coma around the time of our proposed observations will be about 15'', but the majority of flux from the molecules of interest is predicted to be concentrated in structures < 5'' across. Flux contributions from structures > 5'' across are calculated to be weak (<5% of the total flux), and therefore below the detection threshold for most of the species of interest. Snapshot images will provide sufficient uv-coverage to characterise the coma on size scales ~1'' to reach our scientific objective.
Time constraints: To maximize the scientific return, the requested observations should be performed soon after perihelion in September or October 2014, when the comet is visible to ALMA and still close to Earth. The five correlator settings should ideally be observed in direct succession, to minimize the impact of time-variability of the source in order to assist inter-comparison of the different molecular lines.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: H2CO, CH3OH
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This correlator setup/SG should ideally be observed in direct succession with the others.

prj:TemporalParameters.prj:note: This correlator setup/SG should ideally be observed in direct succession with the others.

Imaging requirements: Assuming a relatively compact configuration, the minimum and maximum angular scales probed will be around 0.7'' and 10'', respectively, and the FOV is approx. 25''. The total extent of the molecular coma around the time of our proposed observations will be about 15'', but the majority of flux from the molecules of interest is predicted to be concentrated in structures < 5'' across. prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HNC, H2CO and CH3OH
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This correlator setup/SG should ideally be observed in direct succession with the others.

prj:TemporalParameters.prj:note: This correlator setup/SG should ideally be observed in direct succession with the others.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Correlator Setup: This correlator setting covers lines of HNC, H2CO and CH3OH (see Table 1)
A spectral resolution of 488~kHz will be sufficient to resolve these lines of interest, which have expected FWHM of 1-2 km/s.
Data Rate: The data rate of 12.23 MB/s for this setup is marginally in excess of the policy recommendation, but is required by the scientific objective of measuring as many CH3OH and H2CO lines as possible.
Requested sensitivity and angular resolution: Adopting typical values for the chemical mixing ratios (and a nominal abundance of 10% for HNC relative to HCN), predicted emission line strengths for the proposed lines in K1 PanSTARRS are given in Table 1. These were calculated using a Haser-type model with an outflow velocity of 1 km/s and excitation temperature of 50 K. The optimal combination of spectral line signal-to-noise and angular resolution for the species of interest is achieved with ALMA band 7. The array is likely to be in a mid-compact configuration in September/October 2014, which will provide an angular resolution of approx. 0.50-1.0'' in band 6 and 7. In order to accurately measure spatial-spectral emission profiles, we require S/N >~ 20 per resolution element (which also allows for some uncertainty in molecular abundance and excitation). Integration times were calculated accordingly using the Cycle 2 observing tool with 34x12-m dishes and, default atmospheric parameters and a source declination of -10 degrees. Band 7 visibilities will be tapered to match the angular resolution in band 6 to facilitate intercomparison of the spectral lines.
Imaging requirements: Assuming a relatively compact configuration, the minimum and maximum angular scales probed will be around 0.7'' and 10'', respectively, and the FOV is approx. 25''. The total extent of the molecular coma around the time of our proposed observations will be about 15'', but the majority of flux from the molecules of interest is predicted to be concentrated in structures < 5'' across. Flux contributions from structures > 5'' across are calculated to be weak (<5% of the total flux), and therefore below the detection threshold for most of the species of interest. Snapshot images will provide sufficient uv-coverage to characterise the coma on size scales ~1'' to reach our scientific objective.
Time constraints: To maximize the scientific return, the requested observations should be performed soon after perihelion in September or October 2014, when the comet is visible to ALMA and still close to Earth. The five correlator settings should ideally be observed in direct succession, to minimize the impact of time-variability of the source in order to assist inter-comparison of the different molecular lines.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HCN and CH3OH band 6
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This correlator setup/SG should ideally be observed in direct succession with the others.

prj:TemporalParameters.prj:note: This correlator setup/SG should ideally be observed in direct succession with the others.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Correlator Setup: This correlator setting covers lines of HCN and CH3OH in band 6(see Table 1)
A spectral resolution of 488~kHz will be sufficient to resolve these lines of interest, which have expected FWHM of 1-2 km/s.
Data Rate: The data rate of 12.23 MB/s for this setup is marginally in excess of the policy recommendation, but is required by the scientific objective of measuring as many CH3OH lines as possible.
Requested sensitivity and angular resolution: Adopting typical values for the chemical mixing ratios, predicted emission line strengths for the proposed lines in K1 PanSTARRS are given in Table 1. These were calculated using a Haser-type model with an outflow velocity of 1 km/s and excitation temperature of 50 K. The optimal combination of spectral line signal-to-noise and angular resolution for the species of interest is achieved with ALMA band 7, but additional observations of the lower-excitation lines of HCN and HNC in band 6 are required in order to reach our scientific objectives. The array is likely to be in a mid-compact configuration in September/October 2014, which will provide an angular resolution of approx. 0.50-1.0'' in band 6 and 7. In order to accurately measure spatial-spectral emission profiles, we require S/N >~ 20 per resolution element (which also allows for some uncertainty in molecular abundance and excitation). Integration times were calculated accordingly using the Cycle 2 observing tool with 34x12-m dishes and, default atmospheric parameters and a source declination of -10 degrees. Band 7 visibilities will be tapered to match the angular resolution in band 6 to facilitate intercomparison of the spectral lines.
Imaging requirements: Assuming a relatively compact configuration, the minimum and maximum angular scales probed will be around 0.7'' and 10'', respectively, and the FOV is approx. 25''. The total extent of the molecular coma around the time of our proposed observations will be about 15'', but the majority of flux from the molecules of interest is predicted to be concentrated in structures < 5'' across. Flux contributions from structures > 5'' across are calculated to be weak (<5% of the total flux), and therefore below the detection threshold for most of the species of interest. Snapshot images will provide sufficient uv-coverage to characterise the coma on size scales ~1'' to reach our scientific objective.
Time constraints: To maximize the scientific return, the requested observations should be performed soon after perihelion in September or October 2014, when the comet is visible to ALMA and still close to Earth. The five correlator settings should ideally be observed in direct succession, to minimize the impact of time-variability of the source in order to assist inter-comparison of the different molecular lines.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HNC band 6
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This correlator setup/SG should ideally be observed in direct succession with the others.

prj:TemporalParameters.prj:note: This correlator setup/SG should ideally be observed in direct succession with the others.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Correlator Setup: This correlator setting covers the HNC 3-2 line in band 6 (see Table 1)
A spectral resolution of 488~kHz will be sufficient to resolve this line, which has an expected FWHM of 1-2 km/s.
Requested sensitivity and angular resolution: Adopting a nominal abundance of 10% for HNC relative to HCN, predicted emission line strengths for the proposed line in K1 PanSTARRS is given in Table 1. This were calculated using a Haser-type model with an outflow velocity of 1 km/s and excitation temperature of 50 K. The optimal combination of spectral line signal-to-noise and angular resolution for the species of interest is achieved with ALMA band 7, but additional observations of the lower-excitation lines of HNC in band 6 are required in order to reach our scientific objectives. The array is likely to be in a mid-compact configuration in September/October 2014, which will provide an angular resolution of approx. 0.50-1.0'' in band 6 and 7. In order to accurately measure spatial-spectral emission profiles, we require S/N >~ 20 per resolution element (which also allows for some uncertainty in molecular abundance and excitation). Integration times were calculated accordingly using the Cycle 2 observing tool with 34x12-m dishes and, default atmospheric parameters and a source declination of -10 degrees. Band 7 visibilities will be tapered to match the angular resolution in band 6 to facilitate intercomparison of the spectral lines.
Imaging requirements: Assuming a relatively compact configuration, the minimum and maximum angular scales probed will be around 0.7'' and 10'', respectively, and the FOV is approx. 25''. The total extent of the molecular coma around the time of our proposed observations will be about 15'', but the majority of flux from the molecules of interest is predicted to be concentrated in structures < 5'' across. Flux contributions from structures > 5'' across are calculated to be weak (<5% of the total flux), and therefore below the detection threshold for most of the species of interest. Snapshot images will provide sufficient uv-coverage to characterise the coma on size scales ~1'' to reach our scientific objective.
Time constraints: To maximize the scientific return, the requested observations should be performed soon after perihelion in September or October 2014, when the comet is visible to ALMA and still close to Earth. The five correlator settings should ideally be observed in direct succession, to minimize the impact of time-variability of the source in order to assist inter-comparison of the different molecular lines.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Cometary ices contain pristine material from the formation of the solar system, and studies of their composition provide unique information regarding the physical and chemical conditions of the early Solar Nebula. Use of gas-phase coma observations as probes of cometary ices requires a complete understanding of the gas-release mechanisms, but previous observations have been unable to ascertain the precise origin of fundamental coma species CO, H2CO, HCN, HNC and CS, and details regarding their possible formation in the coma are not well understood. We propose to obtain spectrally and spatially-resolved sub-mm emission maps of these molecules in the coma of comet C/2012 K1 (PanSTARRS), which will reach peak activity around perihelion in August 2014. The proposed 3D maps, including multiple spectral lines from CH3OH and the other species of interest, are required in order to determine the excitation, and therefore the precise distributions, of molecules in the coma. These measurements will provide quantitative tests of release models for the species of interest and will be vital in assisting the interpretation of our ALMA data on comets ISON and Lemmon (obtained in 2013).
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2012.A.00033.S; 'Revealing the chemical evolution of sun-grazing comet C/2012 S1 (ISON)'; PI Cordiner 2012.A.00020.S; 'Paradigm-shifting ALMA observations of the unusually-bright comet C/2012 F6 (Lemmon)'; PI Cordiner
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system
